HED.prologue: The HED Language schema is a Hierarchical Event Descriptors Library Schema Language stimuli and experiments. The schema allows for detailed annotation of neuroimaging experiments that involve language events from carefully controlled experiments specifically targeting the neuroscience of language processing to more complex naturalistic paradigms that involve written or spoken language. HED Language schema allows for annotation of language stimuli on different levels through the orthogonal definition of Language-units and Language-unit-properties. Full sentences can be annotated with sentence-level characteristics while the individual words in the sentence can simultaneously be associated with word-level characteristics. Annotation possibilities are extensive and cover characteristics of multiple languages allowing for comparisons between languages.

node.name: Language
node.description: A specific system of communication, with a vocabulary and grammar, which is used by a particular community or in a country.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment Langue has been suggested as a term to refer to a specific language while the term language in general refers to the high level concept of language and its general properties. However this has never been widely adopted. In context of HED Language as an Item works.

node.name: Afroasiatic-language
node.description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in West Asia, North Africa, the Horn of Africa and parts of the Sahara and Sahel.

node.name: Arabic
node.description: An Afroasiatic language spoken mainly in Northern Africa and Western Asia.

node.name: Hebrew
node.description: An Afroasiatic language mainly spoken in Israel.

node.name: Atlantic-Congo-language
node.description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in South, and parts of Central and West Africa.

node.name: Swahili
node.description: An atlantic congo language mainly spoken in Tanzania, Kenya and Mozambique.

node.name: Austroasiatic
node.description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in Southeast Asia, South Asia and East Asia.

node.name: Vietnamese
node.description: An Austroasiatic language mainly spoken in Vietnam.

node.name: Austronesian-language
node.description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in Southeast Asi, Madagascar, the islands of the Pacific Ocean and Taiwan.

node.name: Malay
node.description: An Austronesian language mainly spoken in Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, East Timor and parts of Thailand.

node.name: Dravidian
node.description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in Southern India, Northeast Sri Lanka Southwest Pakistan and some regions of Nepal.

node.name: Tamil
node.description: A Dravidian Language spoken the Indian state Tamil Nadu, Puducherry and Sri Lanka and Singapore.

node.name: Indo-European-language
node.description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages native to the majority of Europe, the Iranian plateau, and the northern Indian subcontinent.

node.name: Baltic-language
node.description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages originating in Northeastern Europe.

node.name: Latvian
node.description: A baltic language spoken mainly in Latvia.

node.name: Lithuanian
node.description: A baltic language spoken mainly in Lithuania.

node.name: Germanic-language
node.description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages originating in Northwestern and Central Europe and Scandinavia, currently spoken mainly in Europe, North America, Oceania and Southern Africa.

node.name: Danish
node.description: A Germanic language, mainly spoken in Denmark.

node.name: Dutch
node.description: A Germanic Language which is spoken in parts of Western Europe, South America and the Caribbean islands.

node.name: English
node.description: A Germanic Language which is spoken in the United Kingdom, parts of North America, and Oceania and is used in parts of Africa, Asia and Oceania as an administrative language.

node.name: German
node.description: A Germanic Language which is mainly spoken in Western and Central Europe.

node.name: Icelandic
node.description: A Germanic language mainly spoken in Iceland.

node.name: Norwegian
node.description: A Germanic language mainly spoken in Norway.

node.name: Swedish
node.description: A Germanic language mainly spoken in Sweden and parts of Finland.

node.name: Romance-language
node.description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages directly descending from Vulgar Latin.

node.name: Catalan
node.description: A Romance language spoken in Andorra, and several autonomous communities in Eastern Spain as well as a department in Southern France.

node.name: French
node.description: A Romance language spoken in parts of Western Europe, North America and Africa, and is used as an administrative or official language in parts of the world.

node.name: Galician
node.description: A Romance language mainly spoken in Galicia.

node.name: Gallo-Rhaetian-language
node.description: A group of historically related Romance varieties spoken in Switzerland and Northern Italy.

node.name: Italian
node.description: A Romance language mainly spoken in Italy and parts of Switzerland.

node.name: Portuguese
node.description: A Romance language spoken in Portugal and part of South America (Brazil) and is used as administrative language in other parts of the world.

node.name: Romanian
node.description: A Romance language spoken in Romania and Moldova as well as small communities in Bulgaria, Hungary, Serbia and Ukraine.

node.name: Spanish
node.description: A Romance language spoken in Spain and large parts of the Americas.

node.name: Slavic-language
node.description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages originating in Eastern Europe.

node.name: Bulgarian
node.description: A Slavic language spoken mainly in Bulgaria.

node.name: Croatian
node.description: A Slavic language spoken mainly in Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro and parts of Serbia.

node.name: Czech
node.description: A Slavic language spoken mainly in the Czech Republic.

node.name: Macedonian
node.description: A Slavic language spoken mainly in North Macedonia.

node.name: Polish
node.description: A Slavic language spoken mainly in Poland.

node.name: Russian
node.description: A Slavic language spoken mainly in Europe and used in parts of Eastern Europe, West and Central Asia.

node.name: Slovak
node.description: A Slavic language spoken mainly in Slovakia.

node.name: Ukrainian
node.description: A Slavic language spoken mainly in Ukraine.

node.name: Japonic
node.description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in Japan and the Ryukyu Islands.

node.name: Japanese
node.description: A Japonic language mainly spoken in Japan.

node.name: Koreanic
node.description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in Korea.

node.name: Korean
node.description: A Koreanic language mainly spoken in Korea.

node.name: Sino-Tibetan-language
node.description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages spoken in Asia.

node.name: Burmo-Qiangic-language
node.description: A system of communication belonging to the family of language mainly spoken in Southwest China and Myanmar.

node.name: Burmese
node.description: A Burmo Qiangic language mainly spoken in Myanmar.

node.name: Sinitic
node.description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in China.

node.name: Gan-Chinese
node.description: A Sinitic language mainly spoken in Jiangxi province , and parts of Hunan, Hubei, Anhui, and Fujian.

node.name: Mandarin-Chinese
node.description: A group of Chinese language dialects that are natively spoken in most of northern and southwestern China.

node.name: Standard-Chinese
node.description: A modern standard form of Mandarin Chinese which is the official Language of mainland China.

node.name: Wu-Chinese
node.description: A Sinitic language mainly spoken in Shanghai, Zhejiang Province, and the part of Jiangsu Province south of the Yangtze River.

node.name: Xiang-Chinese
node.description: A Sinitic language mainly spoken in Hunan province, northern Guangxi and parts of Guizhou, Guangdong, Sichuan, Jiangxi and Hubei provinces.

node.name: Yue-Chinese
node.description: A group of Sinitic languages mainly spoken Southern China.

node.name: Cantonese
node.description: A Sinitic Language mainly spoken southeastern China, Hong Kong and Macau.

node.name: Tai-Kadai
node.description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in Southeast Asia, Southern China, and Northeastern India.

node.name: Thai
node.description: A Tai Kadai language mainly spoken in Central Thailand.

node.name: Turkic
node.description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages spoken in parts of Eurasia such as Eastern Europe, Southern Europe, Central Asia, East Asia, North Asia and West Asia.

node.name: Turkish
node.description: A Turkish language mainly spoken in Turkey and Northern Cyprus.

node.name: Uralic
node.description: A system of communication belonging to the family of languages mainly spoken in part of Europe and North Asia.

node.name: Estonian
node.description: An Uralic Language mainly spoken in Estonia.

node.name: Finnish
node.description: An Uralic language mainly spoken in Finland.

node.name: Hungarian
node.description: An Uralic Language mainly spoken in Hungary.

node.name: Bigram
node.description: A pair of two consecutive written units such as letters, syllables, or words.

node.name: Letter-character
node.description: A character that is the smallest meaningful or functional unit in an alphabetic writing system.

node.name: Logogram
node.description: A character representing a morpheme, word or phrase, such as those used in shorthand and some writing systems.

node.name: Noncharacter
node.description: A character which does not hold any meaning or contain any regularity in a writing system.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment Chen J. Sun D. Wang P. Lv Y. and Zhang Y. (2022). Brain mechanism of Chinese character processing in rapid stream stimulation. Journal of Neurolinguistics 63 101084. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jneuroling.2022.101084

node.name: Pseudocharacter
node.description: A logogram-like character that contains components/radicals of existing logograms but which is not a known logogram.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment Derivation changes the meaning of a word for instance reverses the meaning or changes intensity. We do not cover all the semantic types of changes that can be the result of morphological changes but instead give a higher level categorization. Further specification might depend on a more semantic schema.

node.name: Grapheme
node.description: The smallest contrastive or meaningful unit in writing which matches either a phoneme a syllable or a morpheme.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment Has different definition but this one is used in the domain of neuroimaging and useful as such as it is distinct from a character in an alphabetic language (letter) but useful. See Bouhani paper and https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/17586801.2019.1697412 (a combined definition and interesting discussion).

node.name: Lemma
node.description: The canonical form, dictionary form, or citation form of a set of word forms.

node.name: Mora
node.description: A basic timing unit in the phonology of some spoken languages equal to or shorter than a syllable.

node.name: Morpheme
node.description: A meaningful unit of a language that cannot be further divided.

node.name: Phone
node.description: A minimal speech segment that possesses distinct physical or perceptual properties.

node.name: Consonant
node.description: A basic speech sound which is produced with an obstructed vocal tract and which can be combined with a vowel to form a syllable or which can form itself or together with another consonant a syllable.

node.name: Vowel
node.description: A speech sound which is produced with a relatively open vocal tract and vibration of the vocal cords.

node.name: Diphthong
node.description: A sound formed by the combination of two vowels.

node.name: Long-vowel
node.description: A vowel sound that is pronounced in a long form.

node.name: Short-vowel
node.description: A vowel sound that is pronounced in a short form.

node.name: Radical
node.description: A graphical component of a Chinese character under which the character is traditionally listed in a Chinese dictionary.

node.name: Language-item-property
node.description: A property of a language item within a framework of language analysis.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment All these properties should be grouped with a language item.

node.name: Clause-type
node.description: The type of a clause.

node.name: Dependent-clause
node.description: Containing a subject and verb and cannot be a sentence on its own.

node.name: Independent-clause
node.description: Containing a subject and verb but can be a sentence on its own.

node.name: Grammatical-category
node.description: Grammatical category of a word, usually marked through inflection.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment Features in Eagles Olia has no top level features.

node.name: Aspect
node.description: Non-deictic category of verbal morphology that describes the internal temporal contour of an event and presents it for instance as ongoing or completed.

node.name: Imperfective-aspect
node.description: Presenting an ongoing or unfolding or repeated or habitual event.

node.name: Perfective-aspect
node.description: Presenting a completed event.

node.name: Case
node.description: Formal feature of several word classes (e.g., nouns, pronouns, adjectives, determiners) that identifies their syntactic function.

node.name: Ablative
node.description: Used to express motion away from something, among other uses.

node.name: Accusative
node.description: Used to indicate the direct object of a transitive verb.

node.name: Dative
node.description: Used to indicate the recipient or beneficiary of an action.

node.name: Genitive
node.description: Used to indicate attributive relations between nouns among other uses.

node.name: Nominative
node.description: Generally marks the subject of a verb, or a predicate nominal or adjective, as opposed to its object, or other verb arguments.

node.name: Countability
node.description: A grammatical category that determines how the quantity of a concept is expressed.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment Countability feature in olia no definition

node.name: Countable
node.description: Syntactic property of nouns that can be modified by quantities (expressed by grammatical number, e.g. singular, plural).

node.name: Uncountable
node.description: Syntactic property of nouns that makes their referents undifferentiated units.

node.name: Grammatical-number
node.description: Formal feature of several word classes (e.g., nouns, pronouns, adjectives, verbs) that expresses or marks count distinctions, such as one vs. two vs. three or more.

node.name: Collective
node.description: Not representing a specific number.

node.name: Dual
node.description: Representing exactly two instances of a concept.

node.name: Paucal
node.description: Representing a few, or small number of instances of a concept.

node.name: Plural
node.description: Representing multiple instances of a concept.

node.name: Singular
node.description: Representing one instance of a concept.

node.name: Singulative
node.description: Representing one instance of a concept through modifying the standard collective.

node.name: Trial
node.description: Representing exactly three instances of a concept.

node.name: Mood
node.description: Non-deictic category of verbal morphology that expresses speakers attitudes as regards the possibility, probability/likelihood, desirability, necessity, factuality etc. of the event.

node.name: Conditional
node.description: Used for speaking of an event whose realization is dependent upon another condition.

node.name: Imperative
node.description: Expresses direct commands, prohibitions, and requests.

node.name: Progressive
node.description: Expresses an incomplete state or action.

node.name: Subjunctive
node.description: Used in dependent clauses to discussing imaginary or hypothetical events and situations, expressing opinions or emotions, or making polite requests, among a broad range of other uses across languages.

node.name: Noun-class
node.description: Formal category of nouns based on characteristic features of their referents, such as gender, animacy, shape, location or directionality.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment Eagles only has gender as does olia. In Olia gender feature also encompasses animacy.

node.name: Tense
node.description: Deictic category of verbal morphology that situates an event (on an imaginary timeline) as either anterior, posterior or simultaneous to a reference point, prototypically time of speech.

node.name: Future-tense
node.description: Referring to an event posterior to time of speech.

node.name: Future-perfect
node.description: Referring to a future event relative to another reference point (not the time of speech).

node.name: Near-future-tense
node.description: Referring to an event shortly after time of speech.

node.name: Remote-future-tense
node.description: Referring to an event in the remote future.

node.name: Non-future-tense
node.description: Referring to both a past or present event.

node.name: Non-past-tense
node.description: Referring to both a present or future event.

node.name: Past-tense
node.description: Referring to an event anterior to time of speech.

node.name: Pluperfect
node.description: Referring to a past event relative to another reference point (not the time of speech).

node.name: Recent-past-tense
node.description: Referring to an event in the recent past.

node.name: Remote-past-tense
node.description: Referring to an event in the distant past.

node.name: Present-tense
node.description: Referring to an event that takes place at time of speech.

node.name: Language-item-form
node.description: The form of a language item.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment Following https://www.w3.org/2016/05/ontolex/ (which is not an ontology for language annotation but an ontology for lexical entries in ontologies) we do not make the form of language inherent to language items but instead attach it separately. The word itself is a concept but it can be expressed in multiple forms. The same is true for a sentence phrase or clause. For some units it is more complicated but there is a spoken form of a letter or grapheme etc. and depending on the writing system there might be a written form of a vowel or consonant. This distinction increases flexibility.

node.name: Spoken-form
node.description: The expression of a language item as a sound produced by a human or artificially made to sound as if produced by a human.

node.name: Canonical-spoken-form
node.description: The regular spoken form of a language item.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment Should be commonly used (although there is no language without accent) only use regional spoken form when this is relevant in context of the dataset.

node.name: Mispronounced-spoken-form
node.description: A mispronunciation of a language item which can still be identified.

node.name: Regional-spoken-form
node.description: A spoken form of a language item pronounced with a regional accent.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment Use when relevant in context of dataset.

node.name: Written-form
node.description: The expression of a language item through a system of writing.

node.name: Canonical-written-form
node.description: The accepted spelling of a word in a given language.

node.name: Incorrect-written-form
node.description: An incorrect written form that does not correspond to the canonical or the pronounced form of a word, but from which the word can still be identified as such.

node.name: Pseudohomophone-form
node.description: A deliberate generated written-form of a word that is not in accordance with an orthographic system but is pronounced as the word based on direct grapheme to phoneme conversion.

node.name: Language-item-frequency
node.description: The frequency with which a language item occurs in a language, or a particular context for that language e.g. formal, news articles, children's television, etc.

node.name: Bigram-frequency
node.description: The frequency with which a bigram occurs in a language, or a particular context for that language e.g. formal, news articles, children's television, etc.

node.name: Word-frequency
node.description: The frequency with which a word occurs in a language, or a particular context for that language e.g. formal, news articles, children's television, etc.

node.name: Language-item-probability
node.description: The probability of a specific language item occurring in a specific context.

node.name: Cloze-probability
node.description: The proportion of people who fill a gap in given sentence with a given word.

node.name: Lexical-role
node.description: The role a language item takes in a vocabulary, like part of speech.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment Sometimes applies to a word or to a phrase that fulfills a lexical role.

node.name: Adjective
node.description: A word that describes or defines a noun or noun phrase.

node.name: Adposition
node.description: Accompanying an noun to express a spatial or temporal relation.

node.name: Circumposition
node.description: Appearing before and after a noun or noun phrase expressing spatial or temporal relation to another word or element in the clause.

node.name: Postposition
node.description: Appearing after a noun or noun phrase expressing a spatial or temporal relation to another word or element in the clause.

node.name: Preposition
node.description: Preceding a noun or noun phrase expressing a spatial or temporal relation to another word or element in the clause.

node.name: Adverb
node.description: Modifying or qualifying an adjective, verb, or other adverb or a word group, expressing a relation of place, time, circumstance, manner, cause, degree, etc.

node.name: Classifier
node.description: An item that accompanies nouns and can be considered to classify a noun depending on the type of its referent.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment Classifiers are subdivided by GOLD into Nominal Noun and Numeral classifiers. OLIA lists classifier under morphosyntactic category unique (a class for categories with unique or small membership). Classifiers can have different functions across languages. In Chinese count and mass Classifiers are distinguished. Given that these might be language specific and there is no agreement in existing standards we have not added subcategories for now.

node.name: Conjunction
node.description: Connecting clauses or sentences or to coordinate words in the same clause.

node.name: Complementizer
node.description: Marks a finite or non- finite clause as functioning as a complement.

node.name: Coordinating-conjunction
node.description: Coordinates elements that are equal to each other.

node.name: Negation-word
node.description: Expressing falsity of a clause or sentence.

node.name: Determiner
node.description: Determining the kind of reference a noun or noun group has.

node.name: Article
node.description: A class of dedicated words that are used with noun phrases to mark the identifiability of the referents of the noun phrases.

node.name: Possessive-determiner
node.description: Determining the ownership of a noun or noun phrase.

node.name: Interjection
node.description: A word or expression that occurs as an utterance on its own and expresses a spontaneous feeling or reaction.

node.name: Noun
node.description: Referring to a specific object or set of objects (living creatures, places, actions, qualities, states of existence, ideas etc.

node.name: Numeral
node.description: Expressing a number or relation to a number.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: dc:source Adapted from D. Terence Langendoen General ontology of Linguistic description http://purl.org/linguistics/gold.

node.name: Particle
node.description: Must be associated with another word or phrase to impart meaning.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment In Olia they use the term Unique and recommends not using particle because of differing definitions. Particle has an older use but the modern definition is well defined and word particle is used in neuroimaging studies (https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11347875/; https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22341872/).

node.name: Pronoun
node.description: A word or a group of words that may stand for a noun or noun phrase.

node.name: Demonstrative-pronoun
node.description: Pronoun used to indicate which entities are being referred to and to distinguish those entities from others.

node.name: Indefinite-pronoun
node.description: Pronoun lacking a specific referent or having generic meaning.

node.name: Interrogative-pronoun
node.description: Pronoun which prompts a question.

node.name: Personal-pronoun
node.description: Pronoun associated with a grammatical person.

node.name: Possessive-pronoun
node.description: Pronoun referring to the possession of a grammatical person.

node.name: Reflexive-pronoun
node.description: Pronoun that refers to another noun or pronoun within the same sentence.

node.name: Relative-pronoun
node.description: Pronoun that marks a relative clause.

node.name: Quantifier
node.description: Expressing a reference definite or indefinite number or amount.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: dc:source Adapted from D. Terence Langendoen General ontology of Linguistic description (http://purl.org/linguistics/gold).

node.name: Verb
node.description: Generally conveying an action, occurrence, or state of being and makes up the main part of the predicate of a sentence.

node.name: Auxiliary-verb
node.description: A verb devoid of lexical content that combines with another verb to realize certain grammatical functions (e.g. expression of tense, passive voice, negation, interrogation).

node.name: Modal-verb
node.description: An auxiliary verb that combines with another verb and expresses necessity, wish or possibility.

node.name: Intransitive-verb
node.description: A verb that does not require an object.

node.name: Psychological-verb
node.description: A verb that takes two arguments, an experiencer and a theme.

node.name: Transitive-verb
node.description: A verb that requires one or more objects to receive the action.

node.name: Unaccusative-verb
node.description: An intransitive verb whose subject is a theme (i.e. affected by the process the verb expresses).

node.name: Unergative-verb
node.description: An intransitive verb whose subject is an agent.

node.name: Morpheme-property
node.description: A property of a morpheme.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment Morphemes can be categorized based on position function and type. A morpheme property can be applied to a Morpheme.

node.name: Morpheme-function
node.description: The function of a morpheme.

node.name: Inflective-morphological-function
node.description: Changing the grammatical function.

node.name: Conjugate
node.description: Identifying the voice, mood, tense, number, gender, and person of a verb.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment Combine with grammatical category what the morpheme adjusted (can be multiple in aggulating languages)

node.name: Decline
node.description: Marking the number, case, gender, or class of nouns, pronouns, adjectives, and articles.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment Combine with grammatical category what the morpheme adjusted (can be multiple in aggulating languages)

node.name: Word-formation-function
node.description: Creating a new word.

node.name: Compound
node.description: To join with another free morpheme to form a more complex word.

node.name: Derivation
node.description: Changing the meaning of a word, usually by adding an affix.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment Derivation changes the meaning of a word (for instance reverses the meaning or changes intensity). We do not cover all the semantic types of changes that can be the result of morphological changes but instead give a higher level categorization. Further specification might depend on a more semantic schema.

node.name: Change-word-class
node.description: Changing the word class or part of speech a word belongs to.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment Combine with Lexical-role to express what the process has resulted in. Follows Category-changer concept in GOLD but instead of extending further HED can fulfil the same function by tagging it together with a lexical role.

node.name: Morpheme-type
node.description: The type of a morpheme.

node.name: Bound-morpheme-type
node.description: A morpheme type that cannot be a word itself, such as prefixes and suffixes.

node.name: Free-morpheme-type
node.description: A morpheme type that can function as a word.

node.name: Morphological-position
node.description: The position a morpheme takes relative to the free morpheme of a word.

node.name: Affix
node.description: A morpheme that is attached to a word stem to form a new word or word form.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment Affix is a categorization of morpheme based on its position. In OLIA this is a subclass of Morpheme. However there are other categorizations of morphemes based on how they change the stem of the word (categorized in OLIA as Morphological processes such as Clitization or reduplication). However since these all say something about how the morpheme is applied to the word we believe these fit better together under the position tag.

node.name: Circumfix
node.description: Position of a morpheme split in two parts, one placed at the start of a word, the other at the end.

node.name: Infix
node.description: Position of a morpheme in the middle of a word.

node.name: Non-concatenative-morphology
node.description: Process of word formation and inflection in which the stem may be modified (without stringing morphemes together sequentially).

node.name: Apophony
node.description: Regular vowel variation.

node.name: Clitic-morphological-position
node.description: A morpheme that has syntactic characteristics of a word, but which is phonologically dependent on another word.

node.name: Conversion
node.description: No change (where a morphological change might be expected based on regular grammar).

node.name: Reduplication
node.description: Duplication of all or part of the root word.

node.name: Transfixation
node.description: Interdigitation of vowel and consonant morphemes.

node.name: Truncation
node.description: Removal of phonological material from root.

node.name: Prefix
node.description: Position of a morpheme at the beginning of a word.

node.name: Suffix
node.description: Position of a morpheme at the end of a word.

node.name: Orthographic-neighborhood-size
node.description: The number of closely resembling word-forms.

node.name: Phrase-role
node.description: The role of phrase.

node.name: Adjective-phrase
node.description: Headed by an adjective.

node.name: Adpostional-phrase
node.description: Consisting of an adposition and its complement.

node.name: Postpositional-phrase
node.description: Consisting of a postposition and its complement.

node.name: Prepositional-phrase
node.description: Consisting of a preposition and its complement.

node.name: Adverb-phrase
node.description: Functioning as an adverb in a sentence.

node.name: Noun-phrase
node.description: Functioning in a sentence as subject, object, or prepositional object.

node.name: Verb-phrase
node.description: Containing the verb and any direct or indirect object, but not the subject.

node.name: Syntactic-role
node.description: Role a language-item takes in syntax.

node.name: Complement
node.description: The constituent selected by a head.

node.name: Syntactic-object
node.description: Complement of a verbal head.

node.name: Direct-syntactic-object
node.description: A constituent which receives the action of the verb or comes into existence by this action.

node.name: Indirect-syntactic-object
node.description: A constituent representing a secondary or passive participant, often a goal, a beneficiary or an experiencer.

node.name: Modifier
node.description: Optional element in a phrase or a clause that specifies a noun or acts as an adjunct.

node.name: Adjunct
node.description: Optional element in a clause or sentence that provides information about the temporal, local (etc.) circumstances under which an event occurred.

node.name: Predicate
node.description: Basic constituent of a clause that expresses a property or condition of the subject or an action performed by it.

node.name: Secondary-predicate
node.description: Adjectival or prepositional predicate that is not the main (verbal) predicate of the clause and refers to the subject or the object, as either depictive (indicating a state) or resultative (indicating the event's result on the object).

node.name: Subject
node.description: Basic constituent of a clause about which something is said; typically, but not necessarily, associated with a specific case (most often nominative).

node.name: Syntactic-Head
node.description: Word that determines the syntactic category of a phrase.

node.name: Language-property
node.description: A property relating to a system of communication used by a particular group of people.

node.name: Morphological-language-type
node.description: Morphological property relating to a specific system of communication used by a particular group of people.

node.name: Analytic-language-type
node.description: Rarely using affixes, resulting in a low morpheme per word ratio.

node.name: Morphological-isolating-type
node.description: Having a morpheme per word ratio close to one.

node.name: Morphological-polysynthetic-type
node.description: Can encode multiple constituents such as subject, verb, object, etc. into a single word.

node.name: Morphological-synthetic-type
node.description: Having a higher morpheme per word ratio.

node.name: Morphological-agglutinating-type
node.description: Words are formed by stringing together morphemes whereby each one corresponds to a single grammatical feature.

node.name: Morphological-fusional-type
node.description: Have a tendency to use a single inflectional morpheme to denote multiple grammatical, syntactic, or semantic features.

node.name: Orthographic-type
node.description: The type of language item each symbol serves to represent in written language.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment Classification of writing systems is complex and these categories are not universally accepted (mainly because most writing systems have characteristics of multiple of these categories). However most writing systems have an overall tendency towards one of these categories and so the categories can be useful to see how large differences are managed by the individuals who speak them. But it is normal that a writing system does not cleanly fit into any of these categories.

node.name: Logographic-type
node.description: Representing an entire spoken word per character.

node.name: Segmental-or-Alphabetic-type
node.description: Representing approximately phoneme per character.

attribute.name: annotation
attribute.value: rdfs:comment These can be further subdivided based on other characteristics but these are most commonly used in cognition research and relevant in research into dyslexia

node.name: Deep-orthographical-type
node.description: Not having a one-to-one correspondence between sounds (phonemes) and the letters (graphemes) that represent them.

node.name: Shallow-orthographic-type
node.description: Having a one-to-one correspondence between sounds (phonemes) and the letters (graphemes) that represent them.

node.name: Syllabary-type
node.description: Representing one syllable or mora per character.

node.name: Linguistic-relation
node.description: Related based on a linguistic property to.

node.name: Grammatical-relation
node.description: Grammatical relationship between language items.

node.name: Agreement-with
node.description: Inflectional adjustment to match grammatical category (e.g. case, number, gender) of.

node.name: Orthographic-relatedness-to
node.description: Connected on the basis of writing or spelling.

node.name: Orthographic-distance-to
node.description: Removed in orthographic or written form (e.g. a measure of how far cat is removed from rat in orthography).

node.name: Hamming-distance-to
node.description: The minimum number of substitutions required to change one string into another string of equal length.
Integers 0 and up.

node.name: Levenshtein-distance-to
node.description: The minimum number of single-character edits to change into.
Integers 0 and up.

node.name: Phonological-relatedness-to
node.description: Connected on the basis of sound.

node.name: Phonological-distance-to
node.description: Removed in sounding from.

node.name: Phonological-Levenshtein-distance-to
node.description: The minimum number of single-phoneme edits to change into.
Integers 0 and up.

node.name: Semantic-relatedness-to
node.description: Connected on the basis of meaning to.

node.name: Antonymous-to
node.description: Meaning the opposite as.

node.name: Semantic-distance-to
node.description: Removed in meaning from.

node.name: Synonymous-to
node.description: Meaning exactly or nearly the same as.

HED.epilogue: The current prerelease of the schema is primarily centered around written language and current development focuses on adding grammatical aspect characteristics and spoken word characteristics into the vocabulary.

externalAnnotation.name: dc:
externalAnnotation.description: An entity responsible for making contributions to the resource.

externalAnnotation.name: dc:
externalAnnotation.description: An entity primarily responsible for making the resource.

externalAnnotation.name: dc:
externalAnnotation.description: A point or period of time associated with an event in the lifecycle of the resource.

externalAnnotation.name: dc:
externalAnnotation.description: An unambiguous reference to the resource within a given context.

externalAnnotation.name: dc:
externalAnnotation.description: An entity responsible for making the resource available.

externalAnnotation.name: dc:
externalAnnotation.description: A related resource from which the described resource is derived.

externalAnnotation.name: dc:
externalAnnotation.description: A name given to the resource.

externalAnnotation.name: dc:
externalAnnotation.description: The nature or genre of the resource.

externalAnnotation.name: obogo:
externalAnnotation.description: Property indicating that an ontology term has a cross-reference to a database.

externalAnnotation.name: terms:
externalAnnotation.description: A legal document giving official permission to do something with the resource.
